advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Yes, it's really him – William Shatner (Captain Kirk).<br> Did they really use VIC-20 in the Enterprise?<br> That would certainly explain a lot of things...<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MBC-550 FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The personal computer 550, an opened door upon you computing future''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #3 </strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 - Before the IBM PC became THE universal standard, IBM was looking for good programs using all the features IBM Basic could offer.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Let your imagination take wing.<br> Think charts, Graphs, Shapes, Images.<br> Use originality, creativity and color in programs that entertain, educate, organize, analyse. And programs that get down to business...<br> ...In fact, if you are interested in licensing your software, we could be interested in publishing it...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1976)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure - Page 2 <b>EXPANSION OPTIONS</b><br><br> <b>HRAM.64</b> - High Speed 64Kb Dynamic RAM memory board with parity (up to a total of six)<br> <b>HSIO.4</b> - Four Serial Port Expansion Board (RS-232C or Current Loop).<br> <b>FPB</b> - Floating Point Arithmetic Board.<br> <b>ADC-2D</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Double capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (360 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>ADC-2Q</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Quad capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (720 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>HDS-5</b> - 5 1/4 inch Winchester Hard Disk 5 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>HDS-18</b> - 14 inch Winchester Hard Disk 18 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>Tape Backup</b> - 13.4 Mb Tape Backup system for HDS-18 or HDS-5.<br> <b>CRT</b> - Hazeltine 1420/Soroc 120. (Other software drivers available.)<br> <b>Printer</b> - 35 or 55 cps letter quality printer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TI 88/4A. The family computer.<br> It's easy. Connect it, connect yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Colour Genie was the successor of the Genie 1, Genie 2 and Genie 3. It was intended to compete with the Tandy Color Computer although it was not at all compatible with its model (Z80 microprocessor instead of a Motorola 6809 in the CoCo)
The graphic resolution wasn't as good as the CoCo, furthermore it was not possible to mix characters and graphics.
However, the machine was reliable and solidly built. It featured a good mechanical keyboard and even a little level display located above the keyboard, which allowed to set the recording level of the tape recorder to improve reliability when writing onto a tape.

emulator.description: the Colour Genie emulator by Jürgen Buchmüller
emulator.name: EACA EG 2000 Colour Genie emulator

emulator.description: A Colour Genie emulator is included into MESS
emulator.name: MESS project

computer.keyboard: Typewriter style, 63 keys with 4 function keys
computer.name: COLOUR GENIE / EG-2000
computer.peripherals: Light-pen, parallel printer, floppy disc drives
computer.ports: RS232, Joystick (2), Light Pen, RGB, Audio

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> EG-2000 WITH JOYSTICKS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Joysticks were devilered by pair in a dedicated plastic case which was connected to the computer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Parallel printer flat connector, light pen and Serial port DIN sockets.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Tape recorder DIN socket<br> • 50-pin expansion connector mainly intended for the floppy drive unit<br> • RF/TV aerial cable<br> • Audio and composite video output jacks<br> • Power switch and cable.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE GAUGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Only EACA computers offered this gauge which was very convenient to ensure a reliable file tranfer from the tape recorder.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MODEL PLATE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Usually, personal computers offered cheap plastic plate where was mentioned the model name. The EG-2000 metal plate is one of the nicer ever seen on a home computer. Characters are embossed and each character of the model name is painted in a different colour. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Colour Genie was initially marketed as a 16 KB RAM model, and later with 32 KB, which explains the second 16 KB RAM card mounted above the first one. The card holding the Basic language ROM is also separated from the main board. This is probably due to the late choice of the Microsoft Basic version.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Video RAM card mounted vertically<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> RF/TV modulator<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Second 16 KB RAM card<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 16 KB ROM card (4 x 2732 EPROM chips) holding the Microsoft Basic interpreter<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Z80 processor running at 2.2 MHz<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> AY-9810, three channel sound generator programmable chipset<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Video 6845 chipset in charge of text and graphics display <br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Power supply unit</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The three RAM and ROM add-on cards</blockquote>
